38722197.review:
Tadpole Treble is a wonderful love-project by the creators of Brawl in the Family, and although it's underrated, it deserves a spot in everyone's library.

Now, let me explain. Few games have made me gawk in awe, leaving the only words that come out of my mouth being "Woah, this is so cool!". Each level has hours of thought put into it, and everyone has it's own genius. They're all beautiful and memorable, exactly what you want from the short rhythm game this game is. If you enjoy music at all, get this. The game a soundtrack to rival the likes of Earthbound. Each track has meaning, and greatness. It's beautiful listening to this whole thing, it's a musical without words. They can tell all these stories in a bunch of music. It's truly fantastic. Well, it has words. Heck, the singing in this game is fantastic. You're lamented by a male tadpole trying to get a mate, and warned of the dangers ahead by a snail, if I recall correctly. If you're not going to get this wonderful experience, at the very least listen to the soundtrack. You can find it on the company's youtube channel.

Oh, and if you liked Nefarious, these guys were the makers of the music in that game. You really have no reason NOT to buy this.

This game easily gets a 10/10.

This game is fantastic!  Its biggest "problem" is that the songs are *so* good and so catchy that I wanted to read the subtitles when there were lyrics.  That caused a couple of game overs.

I was a fan of Matthew's webcomic Brawl in the Family for years, and this game has a similar style and tone (usually lighthearted and fun, occasionally serious...and fun). 

Their customer service was great.  I purchased this as soon as it was available on Steam, and Michael emailed me personally to help resolve an issue.  While it worked fine on Steam, I knew the Nintendo version is where I really wanted to play this gem, so I recently purchased it a second time on the Wii U.

The single player is short and not too difficult (except for Thunder Creek.  You will die in Thunder Creek).  My only criticism is that the first phase of the final boss was a little unintuititve. I hope to see more from Bitfinity in the future

34745664.review:
Заметил вот, что год прошёл с выхода этой замечательной игры (интернет подсказывает что даже больше, но будем считать то ранним доступом), и за этот год так и не появилось ни одного русскоязычного обзора. Пацаны, тут карточки есть! Налетай!

Ну, если серьёзно. Tadpole Treble это музыкальная (но не ритм, как например утверждается в выдержках из рецензий представленных в описании) аркада, за авторством Мэттью Таранто, автора широко известного в узких кругах веб-комикса, посвященного персонажам Nintendo, и его брата Майкла ( [url=https://twitter.com/Mike_Taranto/status/764472408451510273] как то так	[/url] ). Главный герой игры - головастик, который попал в, кхм, пасть цапли, и был унесён далеко от дома. Да, это натуральная "Лягушка-путешественница" XXI столетия. На счастье этого головастика цапля унесла его вверх по течению реки, так что всё что ему было нужно - поймать течение и поплыть навстречу приключениям.

Всего авторами было нарисована дюжина совершенно непохожих друг на друга уровней, на совершенно различные как графические так и музыкальные темы. Уровни представляют собой нотные листы, по которым наш головастик может перемещаться вверх-вниз собирая бонусы и уклоняясь от препятствий. Как правило на уровнях есть "правильная" ритм-траектория, но в целом игрок может перемещаться как душе угодно. В игре есть редактор уровней, где человек, который в отличии от меня не обделён талантом, сможет соорудить свой музыкальный уровень мечты. Помимо этого в игре множество разблокируемых бонусов. Сама по себе игра не очень сложная, но для разных перфекционистов есть различные испытания, которые необходимы как для достижений, так и для открытия тех самых бонусов. 

Тут сообственно и пришла первая проблема которую я получил в игре - не очень отзывчивое управление - я не знаю кто виноват, руки, клавиатура, но порой нужные для сбора предметы расположены или так близко что у меня тупо не получается успеть взять, или наоборот в разных частях "нотного листа" и головастик просто фзически не может успеть пропрыгать по всем линиям. Но опять же, прохождению это не мешает. К недостаткам так же можно отнести не очень то удобный интерфейс. Например чтобы выйти из игры, нужно сначала выйти в главное меню, а в главное меню просто так выйти нельзя - сначала нужно выбрать какой-нибудь уровень и через его меню только можно выйти.

В итоге: 
+ Прекрасный арт, музыка, и вообще в целом вложенная в проект душа
- Туговатое управление, напор на арт-дизайн в ущерб удобству игрока.

В целом 4 с двумя плюсами.

Tadpole Treble is a rhythm-based scroller where all the events, objects or obstacles are perfectly synced with the tune. The gameplay is simple and easy to learn, but it would take some time to master all the treble & cymbals secrets (I'd suggest reading a guide).

Music lovers get a set of unique handcrafted music tracks to swim through, and achievement hunters are going to enjoy their tadpole challenges. It's also possible to create custom levels with the editor.

Everything about this game screams 'made with love', and many small things got great attention (pause/restart the game often enough and you'll [i]know[/i] what I mean ;) )

33589452.review:
Cute and delightful, a little music adventure and a little bit of rhythm game. Story mode is pretty short (under 3 hours even if you're as bad at it as I am, yet the difficulty felt just right for me). There's leaderboards and extra challenges and composition mode, so there's some replay value too. 

The music is what absolutely makes this game. The first few levels are maybe a bit slow, but then the singing starts and that's what makes this game great for me. Moonlight Bayou and Thunder Creek being my favourite levels.

The few negatives for me:  The story comics are cut off left and right on my non-widescreen resolution. The controls are a bit iffy -- I opted for controller, because the button presses were more responsive, although moving up/down with the stick wasn't quite as precise. Keyboard has more precise up/down, but I never could get the timing right for the "attacks".

Overall, I love it, and it was a steal at the summer sale price. The most similar other game I can think of is Ephemerid; if you liked this one, also check out that one.

32701742.review:
I will describe and rate the key aspects of the game in this review, from a subjective view:

[h1]Music[/h1]
The music to this game is very good! You can clearly hear the passion Matthew Taranto, the creator of the game and music, had while writing it. And his music sheet BECAME the stage you are playing on, with the obstacles being the notes themself! But that is not all!

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The music lines in perfectly with enemies in different themes of music and style, from Chiptune 8-bit stage to Crabs-and-snails western. There are also some twists in the core mechanics here and there for a neat surprise.
But be warned, this is not a rythm game per se. The core mechanic is that you dodge the notes that make up the music while collecting stuff, you are not required to press the keys all the time in rythm like you may know from games like Rythm Fever.

[h1]Time[/h1]
Sadly, this game is rather short. You can play through all stages in 1 - 2 hours, but the wonderful music and style makes them very replayable, so you can play them over and over again.
Also, this game features a in-game composer for your own levels, akin to Mario Paints composer but fit to the games style and mechanics. And with a Steam Workshop integration coming up, this means you will have plenty of more stages to play.

[h1]Price[/h1]
It costs 5 bucks, during the 2017 Summer Sale 1.25 bucks. That's somewhat as much as 1.5L of Coca Cola or some chips. But this game provides you with 1000x more fun than potato chips! Trust me, I did the SCIENCE! 

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Every frame is hand-drawn in a colorful, quirky art-style. The game plays in 60 FPS and obviously doesn't need much to run well. The games engine is Unity, so, yeah. 

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
It can be quite challenging at times, but you can play through the game without dying more than 5 times in total. And I suck at video games. So, it's not too hard. But for that, there are "Challenge Flies", which can be quite a deal to collect! So there is something for the people who like challenges as well!

[h1]Final words[/h1]
All in all, I rate this game a solid 9 out of 10 refrain-loops ;).

30762776.review:
The short version:
Do you like rhythm games? Do you like retro homages? Do you like Brawl in the Family? Play this game.

The long version:
I discovered this game through Brawl in the Family. If you like Smash Bros. and online comics, check it out. It's ended now, but it's got some good stuff. Don't worry, this review will still be here when you finish. Anyway, I spotted the trailer for Tadpole Treble in the suggestions after watching their History of Nintendo music vid. I watched it, and thought it was a cool concept. It was also an indie, and as an aspiring game developer myself, I decided to cheer the game on. Since I didn't have my own credit card, I grabbed the game as soon as it came out on Early Access (which was actually the full game sans achievements). It was worth every penny--or peso, in my currency.

Tadpole Treble is part rhythm game, part "platformer" (without any actual platforms), and part music lesson. Levels are built on a musical staff with the notes as obstacles. Cymbals, reeds, and mushrooms add some percussion when whacked, while bubbles, sparkles, and food put some life to the background when touched. The general rule is dodge black, whack gold, and collect purple. The game starts off on a welcoming stage with a calming melody--perfect for learning the basics. The later levels vary in musical genre, theme, and, of course, difficulty. From the suspenseful snaps of Barracuda Cavern to the relentless munches of Piranha Jungle, from the soothing ballad of Midnight Bayou to the shocking chorus of Thunder Creek, from the retro beat of Chiptune Lagoon to the booming orchestra of Con--oh, wait, that's a secret. Anyway, each level is unique and has its own charm, and is worth beating a few times, especially if you're a completionist. Speaking of which, each level has five medals: one for completion, one for gaining an S rank (the highest), one for gaining an F rank (the lowest), one for collecting all the bubbles, and one for nabbing the level's challenge fly (a unique challenge for each level). There's no way to get all these medals in one go, since F and S are opposites, so you'll have to play the level at least twice, and possibly a third time after you unlock something special for gaining a specific medal. You'll probably also enjoy one level so much that you repeat it over and over again. And who knows, you might nab that #1 spot.

The plot isn't anything special, but it's still heartwarming. It's mostly about growing up and determination and whatnot, but it also has some environment stuff, which is something I feel everyone should learn from. Each level has its own miniature story, while finishing certain levels progresses the main. The way "cutscenes" are presented, in comic panels with accompanying sound, is positively adorable, and gives me memories of the old BitF. But hey, that's just me.

On a personal note, as I said earlier, I plan on making a game one day. And watching these devs, I can't help but wish for their success. So if that counts for anything, go support these guys. They're awesome and this game is awesome.

Overall, if you like music, rhythm, and/or Nintendo, go try this game. Trust me, it's worth it.

30061762.review:
Compongo musica, toco varios instrumentos y, al mi parecer, este juego tiene algunas faltas a grandes expectativas: No lo llamaria un juego de dar con el ritmo sino un juego de esquivar el ritmo; tiene una dificultad que no apela al publico adulto; los niveles creados por la comunidad son inaccesibles, lo cual es una gran perdida para su potente editor... por todo esto he decidido solicitar un reembolso. 

Entonces ¿Por que lo recomiendo?...

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

+El hecho de que haya malinterpretado la publicidad del articulo no lo convierte en un mal producto. 

+Tiene la gracia de una obra de Disney y un juego de Nintendo. 

+La sencilla historia y el arte le sera adorable para cualquiera que lo experimente, por macho que sea.

+La musica es una genialidad, pegajosa y apasionadamente elaborada. 

+Hay gran variedad en cada nivel. 

+Su editor de niveles es atractivo incluso para los experimentados compositores. 

En resumen: Tadpole Treble ofrece una entretenida forma de apreciar el mundo de la musica; disfrutando las canciones del nivel mientras ves las notas encajar.

------------------------------------------------------------

Concluyendo...

25777741.review:
What a wonderful game this turned out to be. Tadpole Treble is the debut game by Bitfinity, which among others includes Matthew and Michael Taranto. The former of those two is the author of Brawl in the Family, a really good webcomic I urge you to read. It unfortunately ended before Tadpole Treble came out, so you can treat it as the comic's successor.

Now, I mentioned Brawl in the Family because it had a handful of strips where Matthew got to show off his skill at composing music, and his great singing voice. Since Tadpole Treble is a rhythm game - sort of - these two are both used to full effect. You play as Baton, a newly-hatched tadpole who finds herself abducted from her home at Tadpole Pond by Coda the Pelican (you may be noticing a pattern here). She escapes, but unfortunately finds herself at the tip top of Opus Island. To get home she'll need to swim through all of its waterways, and evade everything that wants her for a snack - which is a lot.

Gameplay is a mix between a rhythm game and an auto-runner, with the twist that you need to avoid the notes making up the song instead of hit them. It has a pretty forgiving difficulty curve, and there's usually multiple safe paths, not to mention a super mode you can trigger that lets you plow right through them (but not other obstacles) after it's fully charged. The stages have a great deal of variety, and all of them feel like they have their own identity. In one you have to deal with a barracuda pursuing you through a dark cavern, in another swimming backwards as you head down a waterfall. 

And the songs! Not all of them are voiced, sadly, but they're as unique as the levels, and fit them all perfectly. I saw a comment comparing them to the Kirby series in how they evoke different emotions, and that's pretty accurate. These guys definitely have talent. 

Tadpole Treble only spans twelve levels and they're all only about three minutes, same with the songs that accompany them. That's not a problem for me, since it's priced accordingly, the levels are fun, and there's a decent chunk of replayability to them as well. There's the obvious S Ranks you can acquire for perfecting a level, and uniquely, F Ranks you can get by skillfully being as bad at it as possible. Each level also has Challenge Flies you can collect by performing a specific task, and bubbles you can exchange for extras like bestiary pages of all the animals you encounter in the game.

I don't think there's a game on Steam quite like Tadpole Treble, and while it's not exactly a rhythm game I'd recommend it to fans of the genre anyway, or just to anyone looking for something colorful, happy and humorous.

25719346.review:
[b]Short Version:[/b]  Charming little game starring a teeny tiny tadpole in a big watery world filled with danger, adventure, romance, badgers, and of course, music!   Squirm your small squiggly self up and down the treble clef to fight off pelicans, lightning, bears, magical mayan deathtraps, horny tadpoles, obese amphibians,  and the supreme enemy of all things... a poor sense of rhythm!

Tadpole Treble is a short, but absolutely adorable game featuring one brave tadpole in her quest to return home / save the world / not get eaten like a bite sized frogsicle.    The core of the game is a rhythm-platformer of sorts;  As a tadpole, you swim up and down an underwater musical staff to avoid rocks and things that want to eat you, while collecting bonus bubbles and accenting the rhythm with tailswings in order to perform daring dives and Ecco-esque superjumps.

Every level in Tadpole Treble feels like a brand new experience.  Each area features a unique musical piece (in a variety of styles), along with new enemies and dangers - and often a playstyle gimmick to boot (from playing in darkness to swimming backwards to warping through Mario pipes and whacking Duck Hunt ducks in a pixellated wonderland).  The levels are all accompanied by charmingly catchy background tracks - some purely instrumental, others featuring pleasantly amusing lyrics.  Clearly, the developers put a lot of love into designing the different areas of the game as well as the thematically appropriate musical accompaniment.  Each and every level feels individually special, and playing through them is a joy.  

The basic game is rather short (you can probably rush through it in an hour or two), but the online scoreboards and unlockable extras for performing certain feats and collecting ALL the bubbles may keep you coming back for more.  Additionally, there is a composition mode for those who wish to create their own musical adventures.  Currently the composition mode seems a bit awkward (both to use and to share your creations with others), but at least it's an option.  Additionally, the developers recently announced that they're looking into Steam Workshop share-ability, so it may be easier to find new levels to play through in the future.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]  
Tadpole Treble will stick a smile on your face - and then continue sticking with you long after you play it.   There are a few minor negatives to the game (the controls felt a bit loose to me, the story mode is rather short, and some of the gameplay mechanisms aren't explained very well in game), but these are easily overlooked in favor of the unusually delightful experience that Tadpole Treble provides.

[i]10/10, would squiggle through childhood piano lessons again.[/i]

25536150.review:
What is the number one threat to the life of a tadpole? Come on, this is an easy question! Did you say Birds? Fish? Human children hunting tadpoles for their science projects? Nope you are completely wrong. The real number one threat to the life of a tadpole is those spiky music note rocks in the water! Tadpole Treble is the story of the life of a newly hatched tadpole that swam a little too far down river and was as a result, eaten by a hungry bird. Luckily, after a bit of a struggle and a few thumps and bangs, the tadpole was ejected back out of the birdies mouth and narrowly escaped the miserable fate of becoming bird food. Unfortunately, now because of her carelessness, the little tadpole was sadly lost and trapped far from her home pond. You must feel terribly sad and worried about the poor little thing. Won’t you take the job of helping the young tadpole find her way back home? You will struggle with the daunting task of collecting bubbles, challenge flies and dodging enemies such as the dreaded music note rocks!

A developer who was formerly a popular webcomic artist made Tadpole Treble. He became well known for “Brawl in the Family”, before retiring the comic series and turning his attention to game development.  Part of the charm of the old comic series is when the artist would break out into a song. Ode to the Minions is always good for a laugh and remains one of my favorite musical pieces. The song can really make you rethink some of your actions in games to date. How, without a second thought, you slay the various creatures you encounter for no other reason than they are there and they might have some money on them. Do you ever think or do you even care what you are doing to those creatures’ families… you really are heartless when playing a game. Tadpole Treble keeps this tradition alive by breaking into songs on a few of the stages as you play.

Tadpole Treble appears to be a rather simple, auto-scrolling, rhythm game on the surface. You actually only have three buttons to worry about Up, Down, Attack. That’s pretty much it. To complete a stage all you need to do is avoid hitting enough things that will damage you so that you can make it to the end. If you do a decent job as you progress, you will even charge up a meter. When that meter is released, it will give you temporary invulnerability that allows you to get revenge on those spiky music note rocks. You can also attempt to complete the various optional challenges on each stage as well. Collecting all the bubbles, smacking things with your tail, unlocking the challenge flies, getting a high/low score, etc. will yield you badges on each of the stages to see your past accomplishments and earn you most of the Steam Achievements as well. As you progress through the game, the stages get more difficult. Now you are no longer just avoiding the spiky music note rocks; you also have to avoid being eaten by various creatures who think you would make a nice appetizer. 

There are not all that many stages in the game, but that actually isn’t such a bad thing. Each stage you play has its own unique theme and accompanying tune. You can see the five line music staff that contains the spiky music note rocks. You are able to move along any of the lines or the spaces between/above/below the lines in order to avoid coming in contact with the spiky music note rocks. As you pass them, they change colour and sound their note which accompanies the background tune of the stage. On occasion you can add to the beat of the stage by attacking optional gongs with your tail which plays their note and tosses you out of the staff for a while before returning. Sometimes you need to time it just right so you can keep out of the water as you fly majestically though the air over the obstacles in the water below.

If you are so inclined, there is even a level editor included so you can start making your own levels. It seems to be quite powerful too! They are currently looking to add Steam Workshop support so that people will be able to share their new stages more easily rather than having to use QR codes to share levels.

Presentation wise, the game looks cute. It has a colourful, hand-drawn, cartoon style to it that is absolutely charming. Each of the levels have their own separate background and theme so very little looks like it was recycled from level to level. The music in the game is all original content and passes through several genres. The notes of the theme being the obstacles you face made an especially interesting and unique twist for the game. It even has the added bonus that if you are handy with an instrument yourself, you could play along just by reading the spiky music note rocks on the screen as you watch someone else play.

Would I recommend you get it? It is incredibly short. My playtime was at 4 hours at the time of writing this. That included me playing each of the levels at least twice, attempting the single life challenge mode, sitting idle listening to the songs in the music player, making and trying my own levels and attempting to do some of the challenges to unlock more things. There is plenty of replay-ability and it will take me a while to unlock everything. This game was crafted with the intention that you will be replaying all the levels multiple times in order to truly complete the game. If you like rhythm games, Tadpole Treble is definitely one you will want to pick up because it isn’t really like any of the other rhythm games that I have tried. Tadpole Treble is unquestionably unique.

25464653.review:
I also covered this game on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fse9rzyxaoE

The phrase "This was made with heart" gets thrown around a lot and I try not to use it very often but boy, I've not seen such a great example of that in a long time as I have with Tadpole Treble. This game really surprised me.

I received a press code for this and had zero expectations for it. I heard it was a rhythm game (which I like) but saw the art style and characters and assumed it was made for kids. I was totally wrong. Tadpole Treble isn't a long game but I had an ear-to-ear grin on my face the whole time I played it.

The story is that you're a newly hatched tadpole who is separated from her family and must try to get back home. Your journey takes you through a variety of environments, each of which have their own original songs and level specific challenges. The songs were composed and largely performed by the game's developers, some even have lyrics and they're fantastic. They're cheesy and goofy but are purposefully so and that makes them endearing. They mix up genres and themes and every song and the level its associated with feels unique and fresh.

The game isn't super difficult if you're just aiming to get through the story but you do have a score and are graded on every level, plus there's additional challenges and leaderboards so if you want to replay it, there are reasons to. When you beat the story, there's also an endurance mode where you attempt to play the entire story non-stop to see how far you can get and how big a score you can obtain.

Beyond this, there's an entire composition and level editing tool included! You have all the tools the developers had at your disposal and they tell you right off the bat that you have full ownership of anything you create. The one glaring omission here is Steam Workshop support. You can generate a QR code for your levels that you can share on forums and stuff but come on, something like this is begging for Steam Workshop! I really hope they're able to patch that in later as I could see a real community forming around it.

Overall, Tadpole Treble is fantastic and one of my biggest surprises of this year. It's a rare opportunity when I can go into a game knowing zero about it and be so pleasantly surprised in the end. It's a bit short but the content is so good, I think it's well worth the asking price. If you like rhythm games, jump on this. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

Tadpole Treble is an atypical rhythm game that puts you in the role of the guardian angel of a small tadpole named Baton who, through a series of misadventures, finds herself seperated from her home and family mere minutes after she was born.  Against the backdrop of a treble-aligned sheet of music, you must dodge incoming obstacles (which are usually notes directly from the background music) and collect points and bubbles (currancy) in order to survive...and make a high score, of course.

This game absolutely charmed my face off.  There's so much character within every nook and cranny of every stage, and even the menus and extras have a lot of love poured into them.  Clearly this was the work of someone who was developing a game that they absolutely had the most profoud respect for, and poured every bit of their goddamn soul into.

For a price of $10 (I got it when it was on sale for $7), this game promises exactly what it's going to give you; a quirky adventure through music and life that is infinitely replayable through the game's "Compisition" mode, which lets you create your own stages once you've 100%ed the game (and that alone is no easy feat).  I've heard that some people have some difficulties sharing levels, but at least you can show your friends your musical aptitude and level design locally.

If you're looking for something different, charming, and honestly fun, please give this game a try.

An original, creative, and fun rhythm game - the music is catchy (I've still got Piranha Jungle's theme stuck in my head!), the art is gorgeous, and the score-chasing gameplay is addictive and fun. The game is short, but with so many challenges to try to complete in each level on top of trying to set a new high score on the leaderboards, there are plenty of reasons to come back to each level after you've beaten the game. That's not even to mention the easy-to-use song/level editor, which is really fun to mess around with, at least if you have music-reading experience. I've really only got two complaints: keyboard controlling is a little fiddly (I honestly didn't try to make any music puns in this review, but there we are!), and my computer lags quite a bit on the faster levels if I leave resolution and visual quality high (though my computer was about the cheapest one at Walmart, so I doubt many others will have this issue). These are minor complaints (puns again) about an otherwise lovely rhythm auto-scroller, and I'd highly recommend Tadpole Treble to anyone.

As a side note, key signatures and bass clef would be nice additions to the composition mode. (Though I guess it wouldn't be Tadpole Treble if it was in bass clef, would it? Baton Bass, maybe?)

25361009.review:
It'll say on my review that I recieved this game free, which is half true; I got it for donating to the kickstarter.

A creative spin on rhythm games with a charming hand-drawn artstyle. While this game has probably a few too many bugs (not counting the flies and mosquitoes), given that it's BitFinity's first game and it's still fun to play I can look past that.

The gameplay revolves around moving Baton the tadpole up and down the music staff, avoiding the notes of the song playing on that level. There are collectibles among the notes, such as healing petals, bubbles for unlocking bonuses, and bonus points if you want a high score. You can also do a tail slap to interact with certain parts of the levels.

Each level is a different style of song, and Baton must conquer them all to get home to Tadpole Pond. There are "boss" levels, but with one exception, you never actually fight the boss, just outmanuever them throughout the level and escape. The boss levels generally play like a regular level with a few extra hazards.

The soundtrack, as should be expected, is excellent. My favorites are Midnight Bayou for being a rather novel addition to a video game, and Thunder Creek for the excitement factor. Other highlights include the winter themed Snowfall lake, and the suspenseful Barracuda Caverns. Given all the different themes, however, I hesitate to call any of them better than another.

To summarize, Tadpole Treble has a few minor bugs, but more than enough content for a $10 pricetag and is an overall memorable, enjoyable experience. I give it 9/10.

25358514.review:
A beautiful, sweet, adorable little game with a lot of heart. The music is catchy and delightful, absolutely the highlight of the experience -- specially a certain "hidden" meta song that I hope everyone gets to hear. The story and characters are remiscent of direct to video cartoon movies, and I mean that in the best possible way. Many levels masterfully perfect storytelling via game mechanics, and you'll often find yourself empathizing for little Baton.

All in all, a fantastic experience, especially for the price. Lots of completionist-style things to accomplish, too! Here's hoping for more from Bitfinity.

25336831.review:
Ah, Tadpole Treble. A game I have been waiting for since BiTF finished quite a while ago. As somebody who highly enjoyed the musical strips, I was looking forward to see what Taronto would do with his own game. And what do I think of it?

First off, lets talk about the absolute best feature of the game: the music. It's such a wide variety of genres, and yet EVERY one sounds good. All of them. I suspect witchcraft was involved. Obviously, being a music-based game, this is fantastic, as you're going to be hearing those tracks a lot. Which brings me to...

The Gameplay! It's all well and good having good music, but is the game itself any good? Well, I think so. The main gameplay revolves around obstacles and items being placed according to the music, much like other rythm games. What separates this rythm game however is that it effectively takes place on a musical score, with the things being placed according to their note. You move your tadpole up and down the score, and can occasionaly attack things in front of you with your tail.

So that's the basic gameplay, but each stage has its own gimmick that makes it unique to play. It could be going backwards, or being chased by Pirahnas, or losing health in the salty water... you get the idea. There's also a lot to do in each level. Each level has 100 bubbles for you to collect, which are the main collectable of the game, a challenge for you to complete, and several medals for you to achieve. And of course, you're scored in each level - with both high scores and low scores being recorded. Trust me, there's a lot to do.

That is, if you're going for completion. This brings me to my first gripe with Tadpole Treble: it's pretty short. I completed the story in about 1 1/2 hours, only really getting stuck on one stage. Beating levels is pretty easy for the most part, so bear that in mind.

The second gripe I have is with the controls. They're simple enough: up, down, and attack; but (at least on my keyboard) the movement felt very loose. I had to tap super quickly to make sure they only moved one layer, which became particularly egrigious when I was forced to carefuly manouver through dense layers of obstacles.

The final gripe I have is with the final boss level, which was very unclear as to how you beat it. I only beat the first phase completely by accident after I'd wasted several minutes waiting for something to happen. The second phase was admittedly fine, but the third phase... I'm still not sure if I was always doing it right and it just took an inordinately long time, or if I was doing something minutely wrong then got it right by accident. Oh well, at least I don't have to return to that level any time soon.

Despite my gripes, I still had fun with Tadpole Treble, and will likely play it again to complete some parts of it. I feel it's definitely worth the price, as long as you enjoy rythm games.

Oh yes, and the art is adorable. :)

EDIT: On replaying to try and complete the game I found out why I was having so much trouble with the Pirahna level: it lags like crazy. This not only makes controlling slippery, but sometimes it can even muck up the scripted cymbal events. Seriously, the second cymbal causes me to hit an obstacle when I land a majority of the time. And this isn't an isolated incedent - I've seen plenty of other people having the same problem. This kills the replay value, since it makes it impossible to complete the game. Which is a shame, as the rest of the game is really fun. I still recommend the game overall, but it's a shame I can't fully enjoy it. :\

25242097.review:
I reviewed this game for Wii U for TICGN.com, but I decided to buy the Steam version to play at college! Heh heh...

The review:

If you’ve heard the name “Matthew Taranto” before then you must be a fan of his Brawl in the Family webcomic series. I know I certainly am, so I was one with that crowd when it was announced Tadpole Treble would be Matt’s (and his brother Michael’s) direct entry into the development part of the industry. It doesn’t have Kirby eating something funny or comedic shots of Solid Snake’s butt or Waluigi’s horrendously drawn face. However, what it does have appeals to my love for cartoons and music in a truly mesmerizing manner.

Graphics

Given how adorable the Brawl in the Family comics look, it’s no surprise that the Tarantos would deliver a similarly charming original world.  What makes Tadpole’s presentation stand out is just how kinetic and synchronized the action is. It almost felt like I was playing through a cartoon musical; there are events that would time themselves with the music. The backgrounds are fully loaded with animation and scenery. Tadpole Treble is the most visually interesting game since the day Parappa the Rapper birthed the modern conventions for a rhythm game.

Audio

Oh…my…God. This soundtrack. THIS soundtrack! It partially seems to be there to complement the stylistic gameplay, providing melodies that people could hop on board with. It’s not a bad thing by any means, since the general compositions fit the concept like a glove. However the highlights of the soundtrack come around when the music goes above and beyond to be as diverse and catchy as it could. Each level has a unique piece, and the instrumentals can range from piano melodies to drums and bass to full-on lyrics!

The music is in complete control of what goes on in the game, and players have no choice but to go with the flow. Because they’ll be having fun anyway. If anything, there is one level that (while the song is still solid) has a portion in which the mood changes rather abruptly. It kind of makes the song lose its momentum the tone had prior to the moment it changed. Other than that one nitpick the audio is an A+ in my book.

Gameplay

The gameplay is easy to grasp. As the plucky little tadpole, you move up and down to avoid the black notes and instead collect the purple bubbles. Sometimes you’d need to whip your tail at particular timings for extra points or to keep away from certain level-specific dangers. While rhythm games often rely on the music to be the basis for mechanics revolving around matching button presses, Tadpole Treble‘s gameplay is pretty much in the music’s hands. It’s fun to keep at the given pace and collect the bubbles as they are synced with the background piece. The graphics also come in to play in the form of surrounding animated animals serving as unique gameplay obstacles. There is life created through the musical gameplay and it does a darn great job at embracing it.

You too can embrace the lively musical cartoon vibes as well via the game’s Composition mode.  You can even make your own levels! And since this is a music game, that means you can make your own songs and share them with others. This is where the game’s inspiration from Mario Paint becomes a lot more evident. That’s because the music creation is intuitive and fun, much like Tadpole Treble‘s own levels. The tools are easy to learn, and the results are ultimately effective.

Verdict

Guys, I freaking love this game. Heart and soul is visibly poured into every detail of Tadpole Treble and all I can really think to do is obsess about those details. It’s like my interests in music and cartoons had a night out and partied at a multimedia theater. As much as I’d want to dish out a couple nitpicks (which I just barely managed to do), I have had too much fun mentally dancing along and playing through the game to care. Seamlessly synchronized and filled to the brim with charm and personality, Tadpole Treble is unquestionably a must-have for your Wii U. I can’t wait to see what else the Super Taranto Bros. will come up with in the distant future.

24193635.review:
Disclaimer: Backed the kickstarter, fairly long-time reader of Brawl in the Family.  So I might be a bit biased!

One of my favourite things about videogames generally is the music, and while some of it took a little while to grow on me, the more I've played this game the more I love its soundtrack.  I guess that's the nature of game music - it really helps to hear it in context, at least at first.  And since this is a game where you have to really think about the music to play the levels well, that probably goes double.  I've had a soft spot for Chiptune Lagoon ever since it featured in the demo, but for me there's also a great stretch of level music for the levels from Snowfall Lake to Thunder Creek.  Then again, ask any fan of this game and they'd probably pick out their own faves.  I dunno.  Music.  It's good stuff.

The gameplay is solid, with a good difficulty curve.  I'm not generally a fan of rhythm games, but the decision to make it a game about dodging the notes (for the most part) rather than hitting them allows for a lot more freedom for the player - and creativity for the level designer.  The gameplay varies nicely, with some levels focusing on gimmicks and others just focusing more on hitting you with increasingly complex songs.  There are even boss battles every third level or so!  The main game is quite short, but there's plenty of replayability if you want to gun for challenges or high scores - which also adds to the good feel of the difficulty curve.  The game is easy to learn, reasonable to beat (heck, I've beaten it, and that's saying something) and pretty darn hard to master.

The art style is simple, cute and effective, and the game's writing has some nice humour, as you might expect from Matthew Taranto - make sure to chat to Etude whenever you get the chance :).

As it stands, the game's only real weakness is with Composer mode.  It's a brilliant idea - a toolset that allows you to write your own tunes and, in the process, design your own levels for the game.  The way that you transfer your saved levels to other players - QR codes - seems really clunky though, and if you try writing a long or high-tempo piece of music you quickly exceed the game's ability to generate QR codes for sharing.  Steam Workshop integration would be a huge deal if it could be implemented.

Other than that, the game's a pretty great deal.  I don't often write Steam reviews, but Tadpole Treble feels like it could use some more publicity, so I'm poking my head over the parapet for it.

PS: one great little joke in Composition Mode: the symbol for bass (the guitar) is a bass (the fish).  Well I laughed, anyway.

23656560.review:
Tadpole Treble puts a fun twist on the rhythm game genre.  Typically, in rhythm games, the goal is simply to time you're button press correctly.  Games like Guitar Hero, Rockband, and Rhythm Heaven are great examples of this.  The other way these games usually play is having you move around.  That encompasses your DDRs and Just Dances.  Tadpole Treble doesn't fall into either of those two categories.

In every level of Tadpole Treble, your goal is to dodge the notes as you swim down the river.  You can ascend and descend the scale to avoid danger, nab collectables/health, or simply to position yourself.  It's an incredibly fun way to play, and every stage has it's own way to keep things fresh and interesting.  A few worth noting are travelling in reverse, changing the theme to 8-bit, and giving you a tadpole partner who serenades you as you swim.  These gimmicks give every level its own unique feeling.

The aesthetics to this game aren't overly complicated, but they're pleasant to the eye.  Colors are well used to contribute towards the mood of each area.  Everything you need to know is quickly communicated to you, with enough time to react accordingly.

The music is excellent.  If you've seen Matthew Taranto's work on Brawl In The Family, or the Ace Attorney Musical, then you'd definitely see this coming.  I don't know much about his brother Miechal, but I'm sure they both contributed greatly to the final product.  The songs have very nice rhythm, and match their areas perfectly.  My personal favorite is Midnight Bayou, as it has vocals by Matthew (He has the voice of an angel).

This game is definitely worth purchasing, even in the early access phase.

UPDATE:  For anyone who cares, I personally recommended this game for the “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award.  I feel that this game deserves it more than any other I played this year.  I encourage everyone to do the same.

This is the first game released this year that I've played and thought was good, and I've played over 50 games (though haven't played DaS3 yet, so don't think I'm saying this is better than that). It's brimming with creativity, originality, challenge, and fun. I was genuinely surprised that it was considered an early access title given it's fun and unique gameplay, level variety, and all the little secrets and tidbits. I can safely say that this is the best indie title of the first half of the year.

It's great for children, as well. I'm sure if only this was more popular, it'd be a hit with the younger crowd. For adults, you can definitely appreciate the amount of effort and passion put into the game, even if it may come off corny, but the challenge is still real. 

It's a breath of fresh air in a market filled with shallow and soulless design/aesthetics. 

If I were to give it criticism, however, I think that the controls are a little iffy. There isn't much of an incentive to hold down the up/down key as it's incredibly inaccurate, the superior option being to tap the button instead. The problem with this is that this can put a lot of strain on your hands. 

Aside from that, it's a pretty fantastic game.

22969932.review:
[h1]Tadpole Treble 蝌蚪高音（暂译）—— 手制粗点心[/h1]

该文将刊发于奶牛精选Vol.6
欢迎订阅@奶牛关游戏社区  或微信搜索Cowlevel关注。
 
假如说有一个蝌蚪经历重重困难回家的故事，还一直有好听的音乐加持，听起来是不是像个迪士尼类型的动画片+音乐剧？那么，如果做成音游怎么样呢？把一些音符做成障碍，另一些音符做成收集的物品，让玩家跟着音乐的节奏而移动，再在一些打击乐器处按下按键，由海底生物，食人鱼，与玩家共同奏出的乐章。看似随便的游戏模式却因为OST的才气而变得十分有趣，不仅如此，游戏还有自由编曲模式，你可以自由运用这些生物作为乐器，谱写你自己的故事和音乐。蝌蚪高音，就像是粗点心，明明看起来就是很糙，却有摸不清的秘方。
 
分条说说。
蝌蚪高音第一眼映入玩家的就是他那，呃，放荡不羁的UI，和十分简单的画面，
还有手写的英文数字，那个字还不好看！不过配合上不修边的其他角色，反倒显得挺可爱的。游戏的音乐部分，则可以用绚烂多彩去形容，有8bit风格的乐曲，也有老式美帝风情歌，当然最强的是其中的几首Vocal，可以说是游戏的点睛之笔，如果论品质，可以说是我目前在独立游戏里面见过能排上前二十的了（大概？）
故事上，游戏氛围十分阖家，从蝌蚪回家的故事，到全篇即便到BOSS仍然有的幽默，都相当有趣。除了短了点，可以说直接可以给动画厂去做了吧（笑.
 
 机制上，不知道诸位玩家有没有看过一个叫做 Mario Paint的游戏，其实最近的超级马里奥制造也搭载了其中一个极其经典的模式，就是Mario 作曲者，用马里奥里面的音效来作曲，其实蝌蚪高音的模式非常像是这个小软件理念的细化，考虑到主要作者兄弟两人对于任系主机的偏爱(他们的作品首发WiiU可想而知），他们肯定受到了很大的影响，但同样，这个创意确实不错。
 
具体来说，游戏并不需要你去呼应大多数旋律，而更多是通过躲避他们累计分数，然后在关键的打击段落通过适时按键来获取倍数增长。非常不本格的机制，但是却让乐曲的创作更自由，与其说是被乐曲牵着鼻子走，不如说是在旅程中与背景音相互呼应，更加自由流畅门槛也更低的娱乐，带来了一种新鲜的体验，挺棒的。

[h1]TL;DR
 “单单凭借音乐就能赢的音乐游戏，结果各方面其实都让人无法拒绝”
7.8/10 +优秀的音乐 +可爱的画风和故事 +编曲模式
      -容量相对较少 -操作在PC上略显僵硬[/h1]

后言：异质化的音游毫无疑问脱离了部分原教旨主义MUG玩家心中的定义，但是这究竟是不是一件好事呢？我觉得 是。Music Game这个词不是专属于某些人的地盘。不过大概也就国内部分人会比较纠结是否本格这个词，但是，谁有资格去界定一个类型的边界呢？一个因为几个游戏和一个玩法而聚合起来的社区？绝对 不是。
 
[url=steamcommunity.com/id/R_Masamune/recommended/]结城理的评测[/url]

22884868.review:
I had the biggest, stupidest grin on my face between booting it up and letting the credits roll. It's just that charming.

I've been a big fan of Matthew Taranto's work for a few years now-- Brawl in the Family was one of my favourite webcomics,  and I've stumbled upon some of his musical work as a result of it. When he announced that he was working on a game of his own, let's just say, the hype was real.

I'm glad to say that my faith was not misplaced. The game's art style and music are top-notch, as to be expected from Mr. Taranto and Co. Perhaps more importantly, however, the game is incredibly well designed.

It's one of those games that's easy enough to beat, if all you want to just to rush to the end (aside from the last couple of levels). But for those wanting to see everything Tadpole Treble has to offer, it's got just the right amount of challenge for old salts like me. It's like the lovechild of Audiosurf and the musical sections from Rayman Legends, and it nails the blend perfectly.

Have I mentioned the grin I was wearing from beginning to end? The game has TONS of character, and even more heart. It's clear that this was a labour of love, and love is the operative word here. Charm oozes out from every pore, the artstyle is adorable (as to be expected from the hand that brought us Brawl in the Family, one of the best gaming comics of all time and easily THE best family friendly one)

If there's any complaint I have so far, it's that, occasionally, the screen comes across as a bit "busy." With notes to avoid, bubbles and health to grab, stage specific obstacles to navigate, and often some other sorts of things to keep an eye on, it can be a little difficult to keep track of it all. It's also a bit short-- clearing it will only take a bit over an hour, though completionists will have a field day and the level editor should help it last longer.

Tadpole Treble is a great game in its own right, but as a first foray by an independant studio, it's absolutely fantastic. BitFinity is going to be a studio to keep an eye on in future years, and I, for one, am looking forward to every step they take.

22853325.review:
The greatest selling point of Tadpole Treble is that it's absolutely oozing with style. Every little detail of this game has obviously been carefully hand-crafted, and you'll find little tidbits of style to enjoy all throughout Baton's adventure. (If you're not aware, one of the primary developers of this game is Matthew Taranto, creator of the webcomic Brawl in the Family, and the style of that comic has very much carried over into this game.) I found myself smiling at little details like how Baton's facial expressions would change in response to events in the level around her, or little moments of synergy between the level design and the music. 

The music deserves special attention, as it's one of the primary focuses of the game. I personally highly enjoyed the soundtrack throughout - I never had the impression that a song, or even part of a song, had been composed as filler, sound to fill a space where it seemed sound should go. Note that this is not the typical electronic-music heavy material you tend to get from music games on Steam. I would actually peg this as closest to high-quality children's music, not unlike the music of old Disney films or one of Sandra Boynton's albums.

Tadple Treble is short, but offers considerable replay value - and it's in that replay value that the gameplay is at its best. Your initial runthrough of the game's 12 stages will likely take you a little over an hour. Most of my deaths on my first playthrough came from an unusually punishing scenario involving shaking off a pack of piranhas - otherwise, simply completing the game usually just requires staying out of the way of obstacles. The interesting challenges come when the game requires you to start taking risks to meet more completionist-style goals.

It should be noted that Tadpole Treble is Bitfinity's first game, and it ocasionally shows in small rough patches - an occasional not-quite-intuitive menu, or a loading screen where it seems odd that the game should need one. Composition mode probably shows this most clearly, with understandable but less-than-ideal limitations to sharing levels, and controls that work well enough but fall a little bit short of a smooth level/music-creating experience. Overall, however, these issues are small, and shouldn't dissuade anyone interested in buying. 

Long story short, if you were a fan of Brawl in the Family, enjoy music games, or even just think the screenshots look appealing, Tadbole Treble comes highly recommended.

22851133.review:
An excellent Rythm game that mixes in a bit of SHMUP bullet hell to keep things interesting. It's full of personality, the characters are adorable and hillarious in turn, and the soundtrack would be amazing even on its own. (Thunder Creek is my new favorite song.) The Treble Charge mechanic is tricky to pull off, especially in the faster paced songs near the end, but it's very rewarding to be able to plow through everything that's giving you a hard time. The final boss battle is a joy to behold, if a little confusing your first few attempts. The art and musing being from the genius who gave us Brawl in the Family is just the icing on the cake!

Sadly, it's not without a few flaws. Despite the obvious amounts of polish that went into this game, there are a few bugs that can't be eaten by Etude. Firstly, I noticed a few times that a cymbal would project a location, only to send me a half-step just above or below where it was listed. In a game where positioning is everything, this can very easily wreck a run of a song. In Piranah Jungle, this happens consistantly on the second cymbal, completely preventing you from grabbing all the bubbles! This needs to be fixed ASAP! Also, I noticed occasionally while talking to Etude that his text would bug out and skip a line of dialog. This isn't too bad, as that option is just there for fun and flavor, but it is frustrating to miss the setup to a punchline.

Another little detail is that it can be somewhat tiresome on the later songs to sit through their intros whenever you have to restart, due to missing one lousy bubble. That's more a problem with trying to be perfect in rythm games in general, though, and the songs are so good, It's not like it's a chore to get to hear more of them.

Overall, definitely worth the money. Just fix up the bugs and you've really got something special here, Matt!

Regarding the game itself, it was a really fun time, and the atmosphere and music are what really make the game special. Each stage has some other animals and marine life that you interact with in some way, save for a couple, and even though everything except Baton really only shows up in one stage, everything is so expressive that you can get a full feeling of each of their characters. However, I should note that the game itself is fairly short, at 12 songs long. You could argue that's enough seeing the low price of the game, and the amount of love that very clearly went into the game. Besides, the Composition Mode allows for theoretical infinite playability.

I enjoyed it. Hopefully you'll like it too.

And, thanks for continuing to be awesome, Matthew. ^^

This game is amazing. That's all I have to say.

A little bit of backstory: I was reading BITF (Brawl in the Family) almost every day since around #100 when I heard that Matthew (the developer of the game and comic) was making a game, I was really hyped for it. I waited a long time, some people criticized him for taking so long but I waited patiently. The wait was worth it.

Then I got an email from Steam, the message was clear. Tadpole Treble was out. Instantly bought it and started playing it. The game seems pretty short but is really fun (and challenging), but I'm planning to complete it.

When you open up the menu you see Story, Composition, Extras, and everything else you'd expect on a menu.
Story is, well the story mode. Short but fun (I haven't quite finished it yet).
Extras, I haven't checked them yet to see if I've unlocked anything
And Composition mode, a mode where you can make your own stages using almost everything in the game. Currently I'm working on some songs to have for friends or when steam workshop support comes out (I wouldn't be surprised if they added it). The song I'm working on now is the original Legend of Zelda Dungeon Theme. It's going really smoothly, the UI for composition mode is very simple and easy to use.

I highly recommend this game to music lovers, BITF lovers, or just about anyone.
The game is currently on Steam and Wii U. Buy it!

22836624.review:
A rare new entry in the genre of music-based games on Steam, set to its own OST and in lieu of attempting to autogenerate courses from existing music, affords you a composition mode reminiscent of Mario Paint instead. The core idea is to move along the stages of sheet music and dodge the notes as they play, while also collecting pickups and slapping target objects to keep things engaging.

The graphics are fairly simple but well realized, the soundtrack is delightful, and I don't suspect the campaign will be very extensive but you also get the editor to keep you busy, all for under $10. My only gripes are lack of any graphics options, the screen scrolling gets pretty jerky sometimes, and the editor is a tad cumbersome (and rather limited if you want to share levels via QR codes). It's still well worth a look.

Recommended to:

22835600.review:
[h1]FULL VIDEO REVIEW:[/h1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F-uEsP1a1Nc
[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[list]
 [*]Frankly some of the best music I’ve heard in an indie game. Each song is catchy, fun and makes the soundtrack alone worth the price of the game. 
[*]A ton of hidden objectives and unlockables that make the game have a surprising amount of replayability. Additional game modes and developer commentary for each level just to name a few.
[*]Free demo of the entire composition mode available at: http://bitfinitygames.com/composition-mode-demo/
 [/list]

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Composition mode songs are shared through QR code which may make it virtually impossible for those without a webcam or smart phone to share songs in addition to being a general pain overall. 
[*]You can only save up to custom 12 songs locally, meaning it is impossible to build up a big library of user created music.
 [/list]

[h1]SUMMARY:[/h1]
	Tadpole Treble is the epitome of what an aesthetic and music focused game should be; simple gameplay made fun by good game design and an outstanding soundtrack.  Each world encompasses a completely different genre and theme that throws a new challenge at you keeping each level fresh even though the gameplay is simplistic. Backwards levels, giant turtles, angry piranhas; I’m hard pressed to find even a single level that is the same as another.  But what really separates the levels is the music. Almost every song in the game is of some of the best written music I have seen in an indie game. Most of the songs are extremely memorable, so much so that I’ve actually downloaded a few of my favorites for personal listening. My only real issue is that the composition mode could be more user friendly, but gameplay wise for 10$ the game is definitely worth a play.

[h1]EXTRA NOTE:[/h1] Game was provided by the developer solely for review purposes with no compensation or incentive to give a positive review. If you have any questions or concerns about my journalistic integrity please feel free to ask.

40767770.review:
我4岁的闺女和1岁的儿子目不转睛地盯着屏幕看我玩了3关，这款游戏的画面和音乐深深地抓住了他们的心，也抓住了我的心。
我非常喜爱这款游戏，旋律优美、曲风多变、富有情节感的原创音乐，融合躲避的音乐节奏玩法，我能感受到作者的才华横溢，我觉得这是一款极具天赋和野心的游戏作品。推荐给每一个同时喜爱音乐和游戏的玩家。


【市场】
外观呈现的粗糙感会成为玩家愿意关注甚至尝试这款游戏的最大障碍。画面和功能方面的粗糙感虽然贯穿游戏始终，但玩过的人会感到这些相对于音乐及玩法的优秀是不足一提的——只是大部分人估计不会亲自去体验游戏。
低龄化的角色和故事设定，可以满足一部分玩家的审美喜好（比如我），但由于购买人群主力依然是青少年，这种设定对于这个“自以为是”的年纪似乎太不吃香，而低龄儿童即使有机会被吸引到，整体粗糙的制作水准也使游戏难以获得更大范围的曝光，进而也就难以让游戏走入家长的视线……
游戏仿佛“被埋没的宝石”，这样巨大的”表里差距”反而会带来一定的话题性，特别是会让玩家有一种“发现了不得了的东西”或者“为游戏打call鸣不平”的心理，玩家之间的推荐我觉得一定是存在的，但音乐节奏类游戏本身市场规模有限，游戏有存在明显粗糙的外表，会使得玩家的传播受到不小阻碍。
对于视频平台，画面的观赏性大打折扣，但可以营造一些和主流游戏相悖的”差异感”和“猎奇感”，动听的音乐和高难度的躲避玩法具有观赏性和听觉享受，我觉得是一款有一定播出价值的游戏。但和其难以获得玩家关注的情况类似，估计也难以获得主播的了解和关注。

40420462.review:
Tadpole Treble is an excellent rhythm game in which you control a little tadpole through 13 levels, each with their own unique music style and feel.
You can only move up and down and slap your tail, so the controls are fairly simple.
But to get everything in this game; that will require some dedication. There are easy challenges, there are fair challenges and there are even a few ridiculous challenges.
All in all, this is a very charming game with an appealing art style and excellent soundtrack.
The songs will get stuck in your head for a while, so there's my only 'bad' point about the game :P
